newsitem.title: USA: U.S West Coast lt. crudes fall, trade to stay thin.
newsitem.headline: U.S West Coast lt. crudes fall, trade to stay thin.

text.p: U.S. West Coast light crudes weakened Wednesday with West Texas Intermediate/Cushing (WTI), while traders said a quiet month lay ahead because of plentiful imports from South America.
West Coast traders said discussion was thin for Alaska North Slope (ANS) crude, with the market still holding at $1.32 a barrel off June WTI, the deal done May 5.
The Department of Energy had not found a buyer for light crude leftover for June/July delivery from the Elk Hills Naval Petroleum Reserve.
The region's ample supply of foreign crude dulled interest in the crude, which saw only 11,025 of 16,100 barrels-per-day (bpd) purchased in last week's auction.
Kern River crude was talked higher at $14.01/14.11 a barrel, with a deal heard done Friday for 1,000 bpd for June.
Wilmington and Line 63 markets remained dormant.
